content.description: Climb the vertical crack on the right hand side of the downhill face of the boulder. Then follow the diagonal crack up and to the left, and top out in the gap. Walk around to the top and check to make sure the diagonal crack is clean before climbing it, this doesn't see much traffic.
content.protection: pads and a spotter. a tall problem with some rocks on the landing.

content.description: Climb the wide vertical crack/flake system (second crack from the right) and top out in the gap. Great introduction to kinda-highball boulders; it's consistently easy movement the whole way up, with solid feet, the occasional hand jam, and a simple top out move. Recommend walking up the backside of the boulder first and locating the hidden jug on the top out.
content.protection: pads and a spotter. landing is okay, theres some decent sized rocks, and it's a tall problem.

content.description: Starting in the pit located between this boulder and the next one uphill, follow the diagonal crack to a slab below the bulge and top out directly above.
content.protection: pads, spotter, and a living will

content.description: This is a prominent boulder in the top rock area. I don't know if it has another name, I just named it after one of the climbs on it that's listed in the old paper guidebook. There are some beautiful crack systems on this tall rock. The vertical face, which faces downhill (see photo), has decent landings. The other climbs around the backside of the boulder mostly appear quite dangerous. There are several more established climbs on this rock, further details are welcomed.
